citations.narrative:
The perimeter fence surrounding the outdoor enclosures for non-human primates, otters, wallabies, and kangaroos, had
multiple deficiencies.
- The fence near the enclosure housing 6 Weeper Capuchins was made of green shade cloth. Some areas were 6 inches
short of 6 feet. The bottom of the fence for that entire side did not reach the ground, leaving behind an approximately 1-
foot gap.
- The fence near the Bearded Saki enclosure was made of chain link fence at the bottom and black netting material at the
top. The two materials were not adequately fastened together creating many large gaps between the two in the middle of
the fence.
- The squirrel monkeys’ enclosure was about 2.5 feet away from the house acting as perimeter fence on that side.
- In the back area, behind the black and white ruffed lemurs' enclosure, the perimeter fence was made of two joining chain
link fences. In some areas, the two fences were not fastened adequately, creating large gaps in the middle of the fence.
- The fence at the facility entrance was made of a 4-foot-tall cattle fence loosely draped with black netting held up by
wooden poles. The fence was not solid or continuous.
- There was no perimeter fence around the front area of the Red-ruffed Lemurs’ enclosure.
- During inspection, the two Red Kangaroos were housed in an enclosure that was not surrounded by a perimeter fence.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures, or a sufficient barrier
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain 6-foot-high fencing for both non-
dangerous animals and non-human primates. Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure
for outdoor housed animals. To be corrected by: 11/30/2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fence surrounding the outdoor enclosures for non-human primates, otters, wallabies, and kangaroos, had 
multiple deficiencies. 
- The fence near the enclosure housing 6 Weeper Capuchins was made of green shade cloth. Some areas were 6 inches 
short of 6 feet. The bottom of the fence for that entire side did not reach the ground, leaving behind an approximately 1-
foot gap.  
- The fence near the Bearded Saki enclosure was made of chain link fence at the bottom and black netting material at the 
top. The two materials were not adequately fastened together creating many large gaps between the two in the middle of 
the fence. 
- The squirrel monkeys’ enclosure was about 2.5 feet away from the house acting as perimeter fence on that side.  
- In the back area, behind the black and white ruffed lemurs' enclosure, the perimeter fence was made of two joining chain 
link fences. In some areas, the two fences were not fastened adequately, creating large gaps in the middle of the fence. 
- The fence at the facility entrance was made of a 4-foot-tall cattle fence loosely draped with black netting held up by 
wooden poles. The fence was not solid or continuous.  
- There was no perimeter fence around the front area of the Red-ruffed Lemurs’ enclosure.  
- During inspection, the two Red Kangaroos were housed in an enclosure that was not surrounded by a perimeter fence.  
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an 
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures, or a sufficient barrier 
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain 6-foot-high fencing for both non-
dangerous animals and non-human primates. Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure 
for outdoor housed animals. To be corrected by: 11/30/2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n
